title: How to Dye Silhouettes Onto Easter Eggs

steps.headline: Prepare the eggs.
steps.description: You can use hard boiled or hallow/blown-out eggs for this method. If you will be using hallow/blown-out eggs, be sure to cover the holes with some speckling or paper clay. White eggs will give you the best results, but you can use brown eggs for a more interesting effect.

steps.headline: Mix the dye.
steps.description: Pour 1/2 cup (120 milliliters) of water into a cup. Add 1 teaspoon of food coloring and 10 to 20 drops of food coloring. Stir everything together with a spoon. Make sure that the dye is deep enough to submerge the egg in. Try mixing food coloring colors for a more unique shade. You can use a store-bought egg dyeing kit instead. Prepare the dye according to the instructions on the package.

steps.headline: Apply a sticker to the egg.
steps.description: Choose a sticker with a well-defined shape. Press the sticker against the egg and run your finger nail across it, focusing on the edges. This will seal the sticker and keep any dye from creeping underneath it. Round or blob-shaped stickers are not recommended because they don't give good silhouettes. You can make your own sticker buy cutting shapes out of adhesive vinyl.

steps.headline: Place the egg into the dye bath.
steps.description: Leave the egg there for 2 to 5 minutes. The longer you leave the egg, the darker the shade will be. If you are using a hallow egg, you will need to hold it down so that it doesn't float.

steps.headline: Take the egg out and let it dry.
steps.description: Use a wire egg holder or a pair of tongs to lift the egg out of the dye bath. Hold it over the cup and let any excess dye drip down, then set it aside so that it can dry.

steps.headline: Peel off the sticker.
steps.description: Once the egg is dry, carefully peel away the sticker. This will reveal the white (or brown) silhouette underneath. Discard the sticker when you are done.

steps.headline: Prepare your eggs.
steps.description: Hard boiled eggs will work best for this, but you can use hallow or blown-out eggs as well. If you decide to use hallow or blown-out eggs, be sure to cover the holes with speckling or paper clay. White eggs will give you the best results, but brown eggs will also look nice. The amount of dye in this method is enough for 12 eggs.

steps.headline: Cut up a pair of pantyhose into squares.
steps.description: You need the squares to be big enough to wrap around your egg. You should be able to get several squares from one pair of pantyhose. You can use old pantyhose, but make sure that there are no holes or runs.

steps.headline: Place a small flower or leaf onto the egg.
steps.description: Ferns, smooth leaves, parsley, and small flowers work especially well for this. Avoid anything too textured, however, as it won't give you a good silhouette.

steps.headline: Secure a pantyhose square around the egg.
steps.description: Place a pantyhose square over the flower side of the egg. Wrap it tightly around the back of the egg, then secure it with a piece of string. The pantyhose must be snug, or the silhouette won't turn out right. If you don't have any string, you can use a twist tie or small rubber band instead.

steps.headline: Prepare your dye bath.
steps.description:
Fill a medium-sized saucepan with 4 cups (1 liter) of water. Add your desired vegetable/spice into the saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium to medium-high heat, then reduce it to low. Let it simmer, covered, for 15 to 30 minutes. The dye is ready when it's just a little darker than you want it to be. Listed below are the color options:
Red: 4 cups (600 grams) chopped or shredded beets. It will be more pinkish on white eggs. Orange: Skins from 12 yellow onions on white eggs. Yellow: use 8 tablespoons (72 grams) of ground turmeric on white eggs. Green: use 4 cups (400 grams) purple cabbage on brown eggs
Blue: use 4 cups (400 grams) purple cabbage on white eggs
Red-brown: Skins from 12 red onions. It will be darker on brown eggs.

steps.headline: Strain the dye bath, then let it cool.
steps.description: Place a strainer over a deep glass or ceramic dish. Pour the dye into the dish through the strainer. Discard the onion skins, and let the mixture cool. Anything below 160°F (72°C) is fine. This will keep the eggs from continuing to cook. This is only necessary for hard boiled eggs. If you used hallow or blown-out eggs, you don't have to let the dye bath cool.

steps.headline: Add some vinegar into the dye bath.
steps.description: You will need 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of vinegar for each cup (240 milliliters) of strained liquid. This will help the dye stick better to the eggs. Since each vegetable soaks up a different amount of water, it would be a good idea to measure your dye first.

steps.headline: Dye the eggs.
steps.description: Place the eggs into the dye. Make sure that the eggs are submerged. If you need to, add a little more water to the dye bath. Let the eggs soak for 30 to 60 minutes. The longer you leave them there, the darker they will be. If you are using hallow eggs, you will need to place something over them to weigh them down. If they float, they won't dye evenly.

steps.headline: Take the eggs out and unwrap them.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon or a pair of tons to carefully lift the eggs out of the dye bath. Set them down on a towel, then cut the strings and carefully pull off the pantyhose. Peel the flower away and discard it.

steps.headline: Pat the eggs dry with a towel.
steps.description: If you are more patient, you can simply set them out and let them air dry on their own. Once the eggs are dry, you can tuck them into your Easter basket or put them on display.

tyn: Beets, red cabbage, turmeric, or red/yellow onion skins
String, twist ties, or rubber bands
text:
Using Stickers Prepare the eggs. You can use hard boiled or hallow/blown-out eggs for this method. If you will be using hallow/blown-out eggs, be sure to cover the holes with some speckling or paper clay. White eggs will give you the best results, but you can use brown eggs for a more interesting effect. Mix the dye. Pour 1/2 cup (120 milliliters) of water into a cup. Add 1 teaspoon of food coloring and 10 to 20 drops of food coloring. Stir everything together with a spoon. Make sure that the dye is deep enough to submerge the egg in. Try mixing food coloring colors for a more unique shade. You can use a store-bought egg dyeing kit instead. Prepare the dye according to the instructions on the package. Apply a sticker to the egg. Choose a sticker with a well-defined shape. Press the sticker against the egg and run your finger nail across it, focusing on the edges. This will seal the sticker and keep any dye from creeping underneath it. Round or blob-shaped stickers are not recommended because they don't give good silhouettes. You can make your own sticker buy cutting shapes out of adhesive vinyl. Place the egg into the dye bath. Leave the egg there for 2 to 5 minutes. The longer you leave the egg, the darker the shade will be. If you are using a hallow egg, you will need to hold it down so that it doesn't float. Take the egg out and let it dry. Use a wire egg holder or a pair of tongs to lift the egg out of the dye bath. Hold it over the cup and let any excess dye drip down, then set it aside so that it can dry. Peel off the sticker. Once the egg is dry, carefully peel away the sticker. This will reveal the white (or brown) silhouette underneath. Discard the sticker when you are done. Using Flowers Prepare your eggs. Hard boiled eggs will work best for this, but you can use hallow or blown-out eggs as well. If you decide to use hallow or blown-out eggs, be sure to cover the holes with speckling or paper clay. White eggs will give you the best results, but brown eggs will also look nice. The amount of dye in this method is enough for 12 eggs. Cut up a pair of pantyhose into squares. You need the squares to be big enough to wrap around your egg. You should be able to get several squares from one pair of pantyhose. You can use old pantyhose, but make sure that there are no holes or runs. Place a small flower or leaf onto the egg. Ferns, smooth leaves, parsley, and small flowers work especially well for this. Avoid anything too textured, however, as it won't give you a good silhouette. Secure a pantyhose square around the egg. Place a pantyhose square over the flower side of the egg. Wrap it tightly around the back of the egg, then secure it with a piece of string. The pantyhose must be snug, or the silhouette won't turn out right. If you don't have any string, you can use a twist tie or small rubber band instead. Prepare your dye bath. Fill a medium-sized saucepan with 4 cups (1 liter) of water. Add your desired vegetable/spice into the saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium to medium-high heat, then reduce it to low. Let it simmer, covered, for 15 to 30 minutes. The dye is ready when it's just a little darker than you want it to be. Listed below are the color options:
Red: 4 cups (600 grams) chopped or shredded beets. It will be more pinkish on white eggs. Orange: Skins from 12 yellow onions on white eggs. Yellow: use 8 tablespoons (72 grams) of ground turmeric on white eggs. Green: use 4 cups (400 grams) purple cabbage on brown eggs
Blue: use 4 cups (400 grams) purple cabbage on white eggs
Red-brown: Skins from 12 red onions. It will be darker on brown eggs. Strain the dye bath, then let it cool. Place a strainer over a deep glass or ceramic dish. Pour the dye into the dish through the strainer. Discard the onion skins, and let the mixture cool. Anything below 160°F (72°C) is fine. This will keep the eggs from continuing to cook. This is only necessary for hard boiled eggs. If you used hallow or blown-out eggs, you don't have to let the dye bath cool. Add some vinegar into the dye bath. You will need 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of vinegar for each cup (240 milliliters) of strained liquid. This will help the dye stick better to the eggs. Since each vegetable soaks up a different amount of water, it would be a good idea to measure your dye first. Dye the eggs. Place the eggs into the dye. Make sure that the eggs are submerged. If you need to, add a little more water to the dye bath. Let the eggs soak for 30 to 60 minutes. The longer you leave them there, the darker they will be. If you are using hallow eggs, you will need to place something over them to weigh them down. If they float, they won't dye evenly. Take the eggs out and unwrap them. Use a slotted spoon or a pair of tons to carefully lift the eggs out of the dye bath. Set them down on a towel, then cut the strings and carefully pull off the pantyhose. Peel the flower away and discard it. Pat the eggs dry with a towel. If you are more patient, you can simply set them out and let them air dry on their own. Once the eggs are dry, you can tuck them into your Easter basket or put them on display. Finished.
sentences: Using Stickers Prepare the eggs.
You can use hard boiled or hallow/blown-out eggs for this method.
If you will be using hallow/blown-out eggs, be sure to cover the holes with some speckling or paper clay.
White eggs will give you the best results, but you can use brown eggs for a more interesting effect.
Mix the dye.
Pour 1/2 cup (120 milliliters) of water into a cup.
Add 1 teaspoon of food coloring and 10 to 20 drops of food coloring.
Stir everything together with a spoon.
Make sure that the dye is deep enough to submerge the egg in.
Try mixing food coloring colors for a more unique shade.
You can use a store-bought egg dyeing kit instead.
Prepare the dye according to the instructions on the package.
Apply a sticker to the egg.
Choose a sticker with a well-defined shape.
Press the sticker against the egg and run your finger nail across it, focusing on the edges.
This will seal the sticker and keep any dye from creeping underneath it.
Round or blob-shaped stickers are not recommended because they don't give good silhouettes.
You can make your own sticker buy cutting shapes out of adhesive vinyl.
Place the egg into the dye bath.
Leave the egg there for 2 to 5 minutes.
The longer you leave the egg, the darker the shade will be.
If you are using a hallow egg, you will need to hold it down so that it doesn't float.
Take the egg out and let it dry.
Use a wire egg holder or a pair of tongs to lift the egg out of the dye bath.
Hold it over the cup and let any excess dye drip down, then set it aside so that it can dry.
Peel off the sticker.
Once the egg is dry, carefully peel away the sticker.
This will reveal the white (or brown) silhouette underneath.
Discard the sticker when you are done.
Using Flowers Prepare your eggs.
Hard boiled eggs will work best for this, but you can use hallow or blown-out eggs as well.
If you decide to use hallow or blown-out eggs, be sure to cover the holes with speckling or paper clay.
White eggs will give you the best results, but brown eggs will also look nice.
The amount of dye in this method is enough for 12 eggs.
Cut up a pair of pantyhose into squares.
You need the squares to be big enough to wrap around your egg.
You should be able to get several squares from one pair of pantyhose.
You can use old pantyhose, but make sure that there are no holes or runs.
Place a small flower or leaf onto the egg.
Ferns, smooth leaves, parsley, and small flowers work especially well for this.
Avoid anything too textured, however, as it won't give you a good silhouette.
Secure a pantyhose square around the egg.
Place a pantyhose square over the flower side of the egg.
Wrap it tightly around the back of the egg, then secure it with a piece of string.
The pantyhose must be snug, or the silhouette won't turn out right.
If you don't have any string, you can use a twist tie or small rubber band instead.
Prepare your dye bath.
Fill a medium-sized saucepan with 4 cups (1 liter) of water.
Add your desired vegetable/spice into the saucepan.
Bring the mixture to a boil over medium to medium-high heat, then reduce it to low.
Let it simmer, covered, for 15 to 30 minutes.
The dye is ready when it's just a little darker than you want it to be.

Listed below are the color options:
Red: 4 cups (600 grams) chopped or shredded beets.
It will be more pinkish on white eggs.
Orange: Skins from 12 yellow onions on white eggs.
Yellow: use 8 tablespoons (72 grams) of ground turmeric on white eggs.

Green: use 4 cups (400 grams) purple cabbage on brown eggs
Blue: use 4 cups (400 grams) purple cabbage on white eggs
Red-brown: Skins from 12 red onions.
It will be darker on brown eggs.
Strain the dye bath, then let it cool.
Place a strainer over a deep glass or ceramic dish.
Pour the dye into the dish through the strainer.
Discard the onion skins, and let the mixture cool.
Anything below 160°F (72°C) is fine.
This will keep the eggs from continuing to cook.
This is only necessary for hard boiled eggs.
If you used hallow or blown-out eggs, you don't have to let the dye bath cool.
Add some vinegar into the dye bath.
You will need 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of vinegar for each cup (240 milliliters) of strained liquid.
This will help the dye stick better to the eggs.
Since each vegetable soaks up a different amount of water, it would be a good idea to measure your dye first.
Dye the eggs.
Place the eggs into the dye.
Make sure that the eggs are submerged.
If you need to, add a little more water to the dye bath.
Let the eggs soak for 30 to 60 minutes.
The longer you leave them there, the darker they will be.
If you are using hallow eggs, you will need to place something over them to weigh them down.
If they float, they won't dye evenly.
Take the eggs out and unwrap them.
Use a slotted spoon or a pair of tons to carefully lift the eggs out of the dye bath.
Set them down on a towel, then cut the strings and carefully pull off the pantyhose.
Peel the flower away and discard it.
Pat the eggs dry with a towel.
If you are more patient, you can simply set them out and let them air dry on their own.
Once the eggs are dry, you can tuck them into your Easter basket or put them on display.
Finished.
